Award.AwardTitle: Workshops: Forming an integrated understanding of function across fungi: NCEAS and Santa Barbara, CA; August, 2016 and March 2017
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although they are usually invisible, fungi occur practically everywhere in the soil. Scientists have known for centuries that there are many different types of fungus (mushrooms, for example) and that they play important ecological roles. Some help decompose leaves, some are necessary for nutrient cycling, some cause disease in plants, some provide food for animals, and the roles of many are still mysterious. Because most fungi are so small, scientists have had difficulty detecting them. With the advent of powerful genetic techniques, however, scientists are suddenly able to discover and study fungus in ways and in places that were previously unimaginable. These technological breakthroughs have led to a new and very different type of problem: so much information is being collected that it's difficult to keep straight -- coordinating the fast-moving research is a major challenge. This award provides support for two workshops in which leading scientists who study fungus will agree on how to organize and store data so that it is publicly available and easy to use, and to develop new questions that will guide the study of fungi in natural and agricultural environments. Results of the workshop will strengthen our ability to detect, prevent and fight fungal diseases of plants and animals.

Two workshops will focus on synthesizing new insights into the diverse ecological roles of fungi, use of sequencing technologies, development of standard practices, design and curation of large databases, and fostering networks of collaborators. Fungal biologists who attend the workshops will be diverse in terms of expertise, gender, career stage, and ethnicity. This diverse assemblage of researchers will be the first of its kind to focus on fungal traits, ecological guilds and sequencing standards. The group will release and refine two fungal databases (traits and ecological guilds) in a dynamic, version-controlled, open framework, and will provide recommendations on community standards and best practices in next-generation sequencing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fungi are critical components of our world, contributing to ecosystem function and the global economy. As many fungi live out their lives at sizes smaller than can be perceived with the naked eye, there are large gaps in our knowledge related to the ecology and evolution of fungal diversity and function. It has only been in recent years with the advent of next-generation sequencing that we have begun to understand how fungal communities function in different ecological settings and how they have been structured over evolutionary time. Fungi are known to live their lives in different ways (i.e., ecological guilds) including as pathogens, endophytes, saprobes, and mycorrhizae, and the important functional traits they employ may differ within and across ecological guilds. However, there is frequently little discourse among biologists studying different fungal guilds. Finally, although next-generation sequencing is increasingly one of the main tools we use to study these organisms, we do not yet have community-approved standards and protocols, meaning it can be difficult to compare findings across studies. In this project, we used this emerging data stream to address previously unanswerable questions in fungal ecology and evolutionary biology at refined taxonomic and expanded spatial scales. The three workshops brought together a diverse group of fungal ecologists and evolutionary biologists, as well as plant biologists who bring interdisciplinary expertise on ecological theory from a closely related field.

Intellectual Merit

In our project, we built a publicly accessible, open and dynamic database on fungal functional ecology. We found that traits such as spore size, melanin content and carbon, nitrogen and phosphorous were best represented in our database. Other traits were poorly covered and unevenly distributed among fungal ecological guilds and evolutionary fungal tree of life.  This database formed the basis for our review papers and is now being extended in new working group efforts to better understand mycorrhizal symbioses. These papers introduce novice readers to the hidden world of fungal traits and ecological strategies.

Broader Impacts

Our workshop fostered a group of participants whose diversity spans the ecological and taxonomic focus of their research, career stage, gender, ethnicity, and location and size of institution. This diverse assemblage of researchers was the first of its kind to focus on fungal traits, ecological guilds and sequencing standards and the fungal tree of life. The group released and refined two fungal databases (traits and ecological guilds) in a dynamic, version-controlled, open framework. We are now working on the final database, a fungal tree of life. We highlighted our knowledge of fungal function and ecological strategies in two peer-reviewed articles and by presenting at conferences not typically attended by mycologists. Both the databases and recommendations will help to bring together and move forward researchers and research on fungi. The group continues to engage the scientific community more broadly through direct solicitations via email as well as via a website, community wiki and listserv.
